title: COVID-19
content: Dr. Peter Hotez M.D., Ph.D., Dean for the National School of Tropical Medicine Baylor College of Medicine, returns to continue the conversation on COVID-19. Dr. Hotez informs us on how we can gauge the number of infected people, behaviors to reduce the probability of becoming infected, and the inconsistency of hospitalizations among young adults between different countries. Dr. Hotez underscores the continued uncertainty in many virus-related developments, but ends with some points of optimism.

title: Reducing the probability of getting infected
content: Reducing the probability of getting infected [22:45];

content: Inconsistency by country in infected young people [27:15];

title: The Impact of Stress on Physical and Emotional Health
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the widespread impact of stress on our physical and emotional health as well as the mechanisms by which it can precipitate chronic illness, dementia, depression, and more.

title: Factors Contributing to Chronic Illness
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., provides insight into the factors that contribute to chronic illness.

title: Preventing Cardiovascular Disease
content: In episode 247, Ethan Weiss, M.D. discusses the latest in diagnostic imaging, blood pressure, metabolic health, and more to prevent cardiovascular disease.

title: The Fentanyl Crisis
content: In episode 243, Anthony Hipolito discusses the fentanyl crisis and why everyone should be paying attention.

title: The Impact of Stress on Chronic Illness, Dementia, Depression, and More
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the widespread impact of stress on our physical and emotional health as well as the mechanisms by which it can precipitate chronic illness, dementia, depression, and more.

title: Physiology of a Stress Response
content: Robert Sapolsky explains the physiology of a stress response and why it’s ingrained in our DNA.

title: Individual Variation in the Response to Stress
content: Robert Sapolsky talks about individual variation in the response to stress and how everyone has a different optimal level.

title: The Impact of Stress on Memory and Health
content: Robert Sapolsky discusses the role of stress on memory and the consequences of hypercortisolemia, as well as the impact of subjective socioeconomic status and social media on stress levels and health.

title: The Impact of Stress on Cancer, Atherosclerosis, Dementia, Addiction, and Depression
content: Robert Sapolsky explains the impact of stress on cancer, atherosclerosis, dementia, addiction, and depression.

title: Concern for System Threshold to Care for the Sick
content: Despite number of tested cases, there is still a ramp increase. Creates concerned for system threshold to care for the sick.

title: Distribution of Total U.S. Cases
content: The distribution of absolute case numbers in the US is more insight-producing rather than total case numbers.

title: Rate Limiting Step in Healthcare Delivery
content: The whole healthcare system was fragile to begin with due to high demand on physicians. Unclear how CDC made decisions around testing. Rate limiting step in healthcare delivery.

title: No Longer a Disease of Young Adults
content: Front line healthcare workers are getting sick. Destabilizing for young physicians. Heavily-hit Covid19 areas are likely experiencing understaffed medical support.

title: Reducing the Probability of Getting Infected
content: There is not a lot of new information about virus survival time on various surfaces. CDC came out with guidelines that loosened criteria of exposure. Convalescent serum could help people remain in the workforce as a form of prophylaxis.

title: Inconsistency by Country in Infected Young People
content: Younger age group in Italy getting ill but not seen in China. High number of hospitalized people between 20-40 years old, accounting for ~33% of hospitalizations in the U.S. Individuals aren’t dying at as high rates as older population groups but they are still hospitalized.

title: Epidemiology on young patients
content: Require good epidemiology on young patients to identify differences

title: Immunity, seasonality, and repurposed therapeutics
content: Non-human primates show that once exposed, the infection should confer immunity. Conferred immunity, seasonality, and repurposed therapeutics. The federal government thinks that the pandemic should last 18 months. Operating under the assumption that the virus comes back in the fall. Or could be anticipating that there is a vaccine in 17 months, but Peter does not think this is realistic. Peter hopes that the model is not dependent on vaccine development.

title: Repurposed drugs
content: Published Kaletra paper interpretation: drugs administered when viral progression is too far gone is not helpful. Didier Raoul preliminary work has looked at hydroxychloroquine (HCQ). Small study reveals HCQ potential but has yet to be rigorously tested.

title: ARB and mechanistic action
content: We are on a steep learning curve around ARB and mechanistic action. ARBs have the ability to block viral entry but on the other hand, it may upregulate ACE2 receptor. They may have anti-inflammatory effects. Preliminary look on camostat out of Japan seems promising.

title: Vaccine development
content: Should we be considering a universal coronavirus vaccine rather than SARS or Covid-19 specific?

title: Practical behaviors to reduce risk of transmission
content: Peter Hotez does not believe receiving mail to be an issue. Real risk is close, personal contact with someone infected.

title: Mental health resource and funding
content: The psychological devastation on the United States […] is going to be almost as big as the damage of the infection. —Peter Hotez, M.D., Ph.D.

title: Points of optimism
content: We are seeing scientists put at higher esteem. At times of stress, people are looking to scientists and in leadership roles. Science communication and data sharing has improved. The heroism we are seeing of physicians of nurses… there is going to be a new awakening behind the medical community… —Peter Hotez, M.D., Ph.D.
